qas.question: The symmetry group of the general theory of relativity includes what?
What else besides  invariance, or symmetry and group part ways in relativistic physics?
Which theory does the relativity depart from?
What are not pair with transformations in the theory of relativity?
The covariance group of the general theory of relativity is the covariance group of how many theories?
What groups do do not coincide in the classical case?
What groups coincide in relative physics?
What is absolute according to the theory of relativity?
What theory does relativity coincide with?

context: In the classical case, <b5_0><b6_0>the invariance, or symmetry,<b5_0/> group<b6_0/> and <a1_0>the covariance group<a1_0/> coincide, but, interestingly enough, they part ways in relativistic physics. The symmetry group of the general theory of relativity includes <a0_0>all differentiable transformations<a0_0/>, i.e., all properties of an object are dynamical, in other words there are no absolute <b7_0>objects<b7_0/>. The formulations of the general theory of relativity, unlike those of <a2_0><b8_0>classical mechanics<b8_0/><a2_0/>, do not share a standard, i.e., there is no <a3_0>single formulation<a3_0/> paired with transformations. As such the covariance group of the general theory of relativity is just the covariance group of <a4_0>every<a4_0/> theory.
